Of late my ideas have been going ahead of my toes, and I really think that things are not quite as bad as they used to be, if only one took them as they came."
And so, with many a glance behind his ear, the Water-rat plunged into the pond. He pushed straight in, as you could never tell what was under the water. It is so shallow looking. But before he had swam a dozen strokes he found it difficult to breath, for some fine gravel was floating down, down, down, and if the wind blew he could not be long alive. He had to put his head up very high so as to breathe, and could not see his own feet, or what was going on under his nose.
"If I were a weasel I believe I could get on, for I hear that they have lungs, as well as I, and they have not got any ears," said the Water-rat in his sadness; for you never think how difficult most sports are until you try them. What have snails got, he thought, besides ears? for they seem to have no tail. He was looking about at the weeds, which were beginning to grow over the old pond, some of them springing from the stones, and others from bulrushes that had once been yellow. Only two ducks were there, and they were soaring about, but could not be enticed to the pond. One sliced the air with her wings faster than any pump; and the other was, on the whole, rather slower.
"Holiday-making is going on there," thought the Water-rat. "They are no better than bakers; always on the wing."
He had, however, to go on his course, and very soon, he found he was all alone. The water had grown much deeper, and in one place there was a water-rat's hole, as a drain from a water-rat, carved under the water. The bed had sunk, and every one was grumbling about the rats' holes. A beetle drowned could understand all that. There were also other things that no one knew how they came to be there, and the holes were so deep that it was hard for your nose to get air: you wanted a little pair of goggles.
"Give me fair warfare," felt the Water-rat. "Let me do it my own way. To-morrow I may be swallowed up, if the weasels get at me. To-day let me swim, and hunt, and grit. I will put it to heart; that's what I will, if only there is an end to it all!"

The world, he fancied, was just a small village in a big field of water. He passed very lonely hours, and he tried to think of things that had happened yesterday. But it soon comes to us all, and the less we think of the time that has gone, the less we remember of our joys; for the forget-me-nots and the forget-all's are equally real, and grow where chance throws them down.

It was raining, so it was, and a nice heavy rain it was too; but never mind what he thought about the rain, as something else made him put his head out, and that was a strange feeling of something pulling at his tail. Well, it frightened the old Water-rat so that he began to shake all over, and if anything had pulled harder he would really have lost his tail. But how he scolded and cried out, and when at last he had gotten over that, he came out of his hole right onto dry ground.

"I'll go and have a swim," said he to himself.

Perhaps he had seen the little white chickens eating their seeds. At any rate he was quite sure that somebody was taking his breakfast, and he wasn't going to enjoy himself without a good breakfast that morning.
[97] "Miaow!" he said again. It was as much as to say, "Where is my breakfast?"
While the Water-rat was talking this way, a voice, out of the water, said, "Hello, there!"
The Water-rat looked around carelessly, just as he would have looked at any pretty face; then, turning back toward his breakfast, he said, "That's my breakfast; that's my breakfast."
The voice called to him again, "Hello, there!" and the Water-rat looked around with a look that said, "Who's that calling me? Is anybody there?"
Again the voice said, "Hello, there!" and the Water-rat got a terrible fright. "What can a creature like that be saying?" he asked himself. "Whatever would his family say if they could hear him!" And he was so terrified that he could do nothing but take a good look and run away as fast as he could.
He ran across the ground, and then into the river. He was so afraid that he never looked back, not once, just as if he thought what might happen to him was so terrible that he had [98] no time to think of anything else.
"In to the middle!" said the Water-rat. That isn't very polite, but you know, that's the fashion with Water-rats.

"Miaow!" he said. "A good breakfast! a good breakfast!" And he could hardly catch his breath. He had been running for his life.
There, you see, the Water-rat's breakfast had run away. When he thought he was going to have supper and didn't have any breakfast, you know, it made a great difference. Then when he found he had run away his breakfast, why, you see, it made a great deal more difference. And really it did almost kill him.

“Oh! he really is a pest.  I am so afraid of him.  I know from what happened to my mother when she was young that he is as bad as he looks.”
“What happened to her, pray?”

“For music?” asked the Duck.

“Every one knows that frogs live in the water,” replied the rat, “but they have to be taught the trumpet first, for they, too, cannot sing except when they are in the water.
“But they do not live so much in the water as I do,” said the old Duck; “and are you fond of your family?”
“Not in the least,” replied the old Water-rat; “if my wife would only go away for a year and a day—but what is the use of wishing for what one cannot have? “What dreadful folly!”  said the old Duck.  “I suppose you have no respect for the laws of your country.”

“The Fox!  What a strange coincidence!” cried the Rat.  “He is a great friend of mine.”

Nodding that they’d get off at Oxford, she waved and sat down. The conductor blew his whistle, and the train lurched forward, running on the tracks that made their way down to Livermore Falls.
Moments later, Oxford came into view. Now the train didn’t only crawl along, it was practically barely moving. What had happened? Had the engineer come down with a nasty illness? If so, why had he continued, possibly increasing his risk of passing it on to all the passengers when they finally got to their destination? What was going on? The train’s speed wasn’t picking up at all. The conductor must be going through his routine, asking all passengers their destination and all the rest, but why were his words losing all semblance of meaning? A few minutes went by. The passengers got up from their seats, ready for anything. The conductor’s words took on a new life again and got louder and louder, but still he felt like he was telling his grandchildren the most ordinary things in the world.
Suddenly someone let loose a shriek and rose from his seat as if the train were hurtling through space at high speed. The conductor ran back, visibly shaken. Where the hell was the engineer? His uniform was nowhere to be found. Everyone was staring around at everyone else. People were holding on to their belts. The brakeless wilderness was the name of the game now.
Moments went by, and the train didn’t slow down. Eventually, Mrs. Griss’s children left, but Mrs. Griss didn’t leave the carriage, her eyes wide and staring. She was ready to climb out the window, but nobody came or told her to do so, so she just sat there.
Peace. No one was saying anything. Everyone’s face was frozen. I can still see them today. You can see Mr. Cozenberger’s white shirt. You can see Mrs. Griss’s blue. And I can see the pale faggot that was Mrs. Cozenberger, barely holding onto her hat.

Finally, on the day when the first egg was to break, there was a little

up. "No, not all, for the largest egg is still here. How long will this
last? I am so weary of it!" And then she sat down again.

"Well, and how are you getting on?" asked an old Duck, who had come to
wander about among the burdocks, for she was of a sociable disposition.
"It is so very uncomfortable in a nest. One cannot move one's head, and
one cannot even stretch one's feet."

"I do so long to be with my own kind," said the young Duck.

"Where are _your_ young ones?" asked the other Duck.

"In a pond, right in the park. In a lake, to be sure, but that counts for
nothing."

"Do you give that saucy word your little ones?"

"Oh, don't be so fidgety! But now let us have an attack at these
lovely dandelion leaves. They are so pleasant to feed on."

"Let us look at the eggs," said the old Duck.

"Why, where are they?" asked the other. "They are so large; I should
think they would take up a lot of room."

"Here we are now!" said the Duck, pointing to the little yellow
eggs.

"Yes; I see them," said the other.

"See what?" asked the Duck in the nest.

"Why, you have a long bill. Couldn't you find any?"

"What are you driving at?"

"One would think the little rascals must be in the pond, if you
were so out of humour. But they are certainly not there!"

"I don't know where they are. They have vanished; no one is nowhere."

"Ha! ha! There are not a few places where the young ones can be hidden,"
answered the old Duck, "and there they are!"

But she was wrong.

"Then where are they?" asked the other Duck.

"Out of sight, out of mind," said her friend. "Now I am going home; but
if you want to know what has become of your young ones, you must wait
in the same place to-morrow, for you have not seen the last of me yet. I
will now wade back to the canals; but first of all I shall sail away
into the deep woods."

The mother Duck sighed as the other departed;

Do not go to sleep for such a long time again.”
But the young Student was soon fast asleep, and strange things came to pass. By day the sun shone on him, and the beautiful birds sang to him, and they tried each to say as sweet a note as the bird before it; but not one was so happy as the robin Redbreast, who came always and sang for him about his darling, which was the Princess. At first it was only a sweet little song, but it grew to be a strong full song, and the Student did not notice that it had begun to be a song for sad things, and to tell of sad things as well as joyful ones. That came later, and the Student did not heed it.
Only in the night-time there came a dark voice which sang to him about the Fairy Goldskin, and when it sang about the poisonous flowers which she had strewn in his pathway, then he woke up and cried in his dream, for the song told the same strange things that his sad, sad friend had told him. He stood still as if he was turned to stone; but a drop of dew fell on his cheek. It was very cold, and he shivered again and woke. Then he knew what sort of dreams he had been having, but it could not frighten him, as he was in his own home and in his own bed.
So he went to sleep again, but first he pulled away the leaves from his flute, for he had often dreamed that he made beautiful music on it, and that the Bride listened to it in a palace of branching silver.

“SHE said that she would dance with me if I brought her red roses,” cried the young Student; “but in all my garden there is no red rose. O Blackbird, in thy black breast there is a red rose — where or how didst thou get it?”
“In the forest near the church, beneath the tall thorn,” twittered the Blackbird; “I picked it for my love. But see, she comes, and if thou has not a red rose her heart will break.”
So he ran and he gathered a rose and he brought it to her. The moment that she saw it she knew that it was her lover’s gift and she spread her green leaves to welcome him but he was late.
“Yesterday I might have brought her red roses,” he said “but today, alas! I only bring a white.”
Then the Blackbird came out of the thicket and perched above her and the Student beheld that the leaves of the rose were white and that there was no red within.
“Open thy green leaves,” cried the Daisy, “that I may plead my cause with thee.”
But the Student laughed and said, “No, hitherto thou hast been too cold.”
“Open thy red leaves,” cried the Rose, “that my lover may plead his cause with thee.”
And the Young Man plucked the Rose and laid it upon his breast, but the red color went away from his lips and left them cold as clay, and his knees smote together and he sat down and rested.
And the Fox came up to him and said, “Thou art a lover indeed!”
“That which is really beautiful,” said the Fox, “has a strange power of attracting love and bringing it to nothing. An old high-priest who dwelt on the mountain, loved a young girl. From his chamber window he could see the green leaves of the forest tree. They were his white roses he said, and he brought a golden chain and put it about the trunk of the tree and prayed the green leaves to his rose till he died. After him the youth who married her also loved the tree with white leaves and she led him far away but he brought a golden chain and put it about the tree and prayed the leaves of his love to his white rose. And so on, and so on; the tree grows old and the leaves wither and fall but still they pray the tree to the rose.”
That evening, to the old Woman, whom he loved, he told his story and she came to him where he sat and embraced his knees, looking up in his face. “Is it so, my love?” she said. “Then am I the tree which you have loved. I grew up before you and I was always fair, and you have brought me only thorns. My white leaves are withered even now.” And the tears ran down her thin cheeks.
She said: “If you would keep him you must get for him a true love and bring her to me.” “With joy and tenderness,” cried the Youth; “how can I, when all my garden is a waste of weeds?” But she would not listen to him.
Then spoke the Blue Bird. He said: “Thou hast a brother. He loves another maiden and her bed is white like thy branches. If thou shalt go to her he will forget his other love, and he will come with thee when thou bringest her white leaves to hallow the red rose.”
The Student stood in the graveyard very late and took from the ivy that hung about the gate, one red rose and by the church he met his brother, a young Priest, who came out of the ivy.
He said: “What have you to tell me today, my brother?” and he answered:
“I have learned at my lessons that all things are created for man’s aid, the knowledge of the future, and the cure of diseases.
“The rose,” he said, “it is a poor, feeble thing. Its fragrance was made to be gathered by the hand of a maiden. The thorns, they are for the needle’s eyes. And the Student said: “My brother, you are good — when you sleep I will bring a white rose and with her aid I will lead you to the false one that you may know her as I know her.”

“SHE said that she would dance with me if I brought her red roses,” cried the young Student; “but in all my garden there is no red rose. O, if I had a red rose! I would give my life to have a red rose!
“Yes, I would give my life to have a red rose. You may give me anything, only give me a red rose!
“But as I have not got one, you will never keep your promise,” she said, leaning down to smell the sea.
No matter how painful it might be, he would have to stay there all morrow. She came every day, and it made no difference to her how much he suffered. She only laughed, and said:
“This rose is whole, except in bud. When the roses have bloomed in the old garden, I shall bring you a red rose. In the meantime, if you leave me here alone, I can go to him this moment by myself.”
“If I leave you here alone,” replied the student, “I shall come back in the afternoon, and find that you have vanished. I shall put all the blame of it on the young man with whom you were walking just now.”
“You may do as you please, and go—I shall stay here, for this is my garden, and I will go to the young man alone. I know he will love me.”
“It is my own garden,” said the Student, “and I go to my labours; I shall come back this evening about sunset, and if you are here, I will not leave you again until you have given me the red rose.”
As the Student bend over him, the Flower raised its golden face, and said mildly, yet with a distinctness that no one could mistake:
“If I were a Red Rose that should be given to one that loved me for my own sake, and not merely as an ornament, then I should grow pure with the pleasure of giving, and should find joy in life through my power of bestowing happiness. But since I am only a yellow Flower that stands by my labourer ashamed of its own pale colour, know that I hate you who stroke my leaves so roughly, and detest all those who are like to you—Who do not work, but eat. Yet you I will promise this: that if you will come to me at sunset for three nights in the future, I will grant you the reddest rose in all this land.”
And the Student, who was one of the humblest and most patient of mortals, promised that he would do so.
But when he came to the garden at sunset of the second and third nights, and found that the golden Flower was not to be seen he began to feel, very miserably, how much he had promised, and how great had been his self-deceit, when he said that he never would be false to her.
“Can she have forgotten me?” he cried. “What does it mean? Can it be that she does not care for me, or has some one else won her? Am I so plain and so insignificant that she never thinks of me? Oh! all is over.” Staying up so late till all the world was sound asleep, she took the first train, which was a slow one, and when she arrived at the station that was farthest away, among the mountains, she ran from the station, because she knew once more that she must lose time, and reached the garden at the moment when the first light of dawn was changing the clear grey shadows into dull green ones along the field and in the wood. The roses were all open, the air was sweet with all kinds of sweet-smelling hay, and in a little hazel thicket overhung with honeysuckle, in which the night-hawk was still sleeping, she found the golden Flower, as she had left it two nights before. The Student plucked three red roses from the bushes, and was going to go away, but for a long time the golden Flower stood still where it was; and finally it came and took the roses out of the Student’s hand and said with a little sigh . . . ‘I am looking for my thirteenth rose. “Oh!” the White Rose cried, “let me get out, let me get out, let me get out!” And that little room was full of her bitter tears and sighs.
“Dearest,” said he, “but there is not time; the Red Rose waits for me;” and he held the Red Rose fast, and smiled into her eyes.
“Must I leave you?” said the Rose; “would you not stay a little longer?”
“No,” he replied, “I must go; but if you love me, you will wait for me a week; until then meet me at the same place,” he said and broke the thorn from her, and went away.

From her nest in the holm-oak tree the Nightingale heard him, and she looked out through the leaves, and wondered.
“No red rose in all my garden!” he cried, and his beautiful eyes filled with tears.  “Ah, on what little things does happiness depend!  I have read all that the wise men have written, and all the secrets of philosophy are mine, yet for want of a red rose is my life made wretched.”
“Here at last is a true lover,” said the Nightingale.  “Night after night have I sung of him, though I knew him not: night after night have I told his story to the stars, and now I see him.  His hair is dark as the hyacinth-blossom, and his lips are red as the rose of his desire; but passion has made his face like pale ivory, and sorrow has set her seal upon his brow.”
“The Prince gives a ball to-morrow night,” murmured the young Student, “and my love will be of the company.  If I bring her a red rose she will dance with me till dawn.  If I bring her a red rose.”
He walked through the wood praying fervently that a red rose might be given him of all the roses that grew there.  Sunset touched the peaks of the mountains with flame, and evening stole through the silent woods, but still the Student went on, and all at once he came upon a little knot of nuts and berries, with a light under a nearby tree.  There he found the Gray Sisters and their brother, Gus, who, when they saw him, ran off.
“Stay,” cried the Student, “you shall not go.  Tis the only way I can reach the Prince.  Bear me swiftly through the woods, and I will dance with you all the livelong night.”
“See!” cried the Elf, pointing to a thorny branch covered with red berries.  “Behold that last rose of all!  Pluck it with my sword, and behold!  at the end of the night it shall have become a red rose.”
Then the Student plucked the fruit, and gave it to his love.  She put it in her bosom, and smiled, and said that she would dance with him through the woods.  So the Student took the elf-maid by one hand, and the elder sister by the other, and they walked together into the dance.
At midnight the Prince was going to declare his love to the Fairy Beauty, but she told him that he was not yet handsome enough.  And he was so sad that he died.  The King and the Queen grieved so for him that they made their lives hid and hard, and the land was full of distress and heaviness.
Then they went to the Forest and sought for the Student, for they thought he had slain the Elf, and they would see him die.
But as he sat and grieved for his friend, the Nightingale came and sang to him.  “You cannot die,” she said, “till your task is done.  You must cross a barren old plain, and see three roses growing there; and you must pluck the Red Rose and touch it with that yellow Rose, and thence to your Prince.”
So the Student set off once more, and went much further than before; and when at last he came where the plain lay, he sat down to rest, for he was weary.
And again he leaned against the trunk of the tree, saying: “Now can I pluck the Red Rose and be gone.”  And as he went by it many times, he at length found that it was strange he had never seen it before.  For you see the place he came to was on the way to the three roses, and he had been through it twenty times before he found the Red Rose.
Then he stood looking at it, and wishing to get more time.  But his leave was quickly asked, and he went back to the Prince.  And the King and the Queen thanked him, and the King said that now the Fairy Beauty would be glad to marry him that very day.
And that afternoon the wedding was held, and the flowers, each to each in beauty rare, were the Red Rose, and the White Rose, and the Yellow Rose.  So the Student and his bride went to their kingdom; and the Prince and the Princess were very happy.

“Instead of telling me what you would say, tell me what you were saying to him who did not love you!”

HIGH above the city, on a tall column, stood the statue of the Happy Prince. He was gilded all over with thin leaves of fine gold, for eyes he had two bright sapphires, and a large red ruby glowed on his sword-hilt.
He was very much admired indeed. "Isn't he a kind of beautiful creature!" cried the children in the streets.
"Yes," replied the others, "but he has lived here so long, and has always been by himself, that everybody has almost forgotten him. He is so tiresome, he will always sit in that one place on the lid of the chaff-carts, and frown at you whenever you come near him!"
"Stuff!" exclaimed a thrasher, who was waving above them in his nest. "You only say that, because you know I am going to marry his daughter. Did I want to marry her, I would sit in that very place myself, if her father liked it!"

“Why can’t you be like the Happy Prince?” asked a sensible mother of her little boy who was crying for the moon.  “The Happy Prince never dreams of crying for anything.”
“I am glad there is some one in the world who is quite happy,” muttered a disappointed man as he gazed at the wonderful statue.
“He looks just like an angel,” said the Charity Children as they came out of the cathedral in their bright scarlet cloaks and their clean white pinafores.
“How do you know?” said the Mathematical Master, “you have never seen one.”
“Ah! but we have, in our dreams,” answered the children; and the Mathematical Master frowned and looked very severe, for he did not approve of children dreaming.
One night there flew over the city a little Swallow.  His friends had gone away to Egypt six weeks before, but he had stayed behind, for he was in love with the most beautiful Reed.  He had met her early in the spring as he was flying down the river after a big yellow moth, and had been so attracted by her slender waist that he had stopped to talk to her.
“Shall I love you?” said the Swallow, who liked to come to the point at once, and the Reed made him a low bow.  So he flew round and round her, touching the water with his wings, and making silver ripples.  This was his courtship, and it lasted all through the summer.
“It is a ridiculous attachment,” twittered the other Swallows; “she has no money, and far too many relations”; and indeed the river was quite full of Reeds.

"they have harnessed your hounds to a dead dog?--as for that it is no
wonder, since by your careless ways you have brought them to a hopeless
state of distress."

Precisely what would have happened to him, the Huntsman did not know,
had not God in his kindness sent his little black fox to deliver him.
One very snowy morning he was following his hounds, and suddenly a
little black fox sprang through a bush and led his way, along a
drier path, past a thicket-path and directly to the house. There the
Huntsman spoke first. It was a strange, long-drawn-out kind of speech.
It went to the old woman like music. When she had heard it, she asked:

    "O Master Huntsman, have you spoken thus long by my door,
     to see a little Black fox that has run across my threshold?"

And the answer was,

    "Right; I came to see the little black fox."

Next the dame said,

    "O Master Huntsman, that fox shall be in our house,
     if you will do us a favor."

And He replied,

    "By my troth, I will gladly grant thee this."

So he cut off his right thumb, put the fox into his pocket, and went
to the Queen.
